awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the University of Nevada Las Vegas will support the training of ten undergraduates for 10 weeks during the summers of 2018-20. The goal of the program is to provide students with research opportunities that investigate evolutionary change using prokaryotic, eukaryotic and viral models. The REU program takes a holistic approach towards training undergraduates and the co-curricular program integrates three modules: Working like a Scientist, Science Communication, and Career Exploration. Working like a Scientist asks the participants to take ownership of their project by formulating hypotheses, planning experiments, analyzing data, and reading primary literature. The Science Communication module provides the participants with the opportunity to speak at group meetings, receive mentoring on preparing an abstract, and present at the Summer Research Symposium. The Career Exploration module consists of presentations by REU mentors on possible career trajectories, and the participants initiating Individual Development Plans.  Participants will use an online IDP program to reflect upon and identify milestones required to achieve potential careers. 

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students will be trained over the 3 year period. Students from underrepresented groups, first generation to attend college, and those from colleges with limited research opportunities are encouraged to apply. An underlying goal is for participants to gain the required technical, communication, and goal setting skills that allow them to transition from trainee to apprentice scientist.  Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. Applications are accepted online.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting https://faculty.unlv.edu/microreu/ or by contacting the PI, Dr. Kurt Regner at kurt.regner@unlv.edu or the co-PI, Dr. Eduardo Robleto at eduardo.robleto@unlv.edu.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF NEVADA SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The REU Site: Mechanisms of Evolution (MOE) at the University of Nevada Las Vegas provided 38 students with a 10-week apprentice-style internship with projects investigating evolutionary change in prokaryotic, eukaryotic, and viral models. The program aims to establish an authentic research experience for undergraduates that captivates their imagination while preparing them for future careers in science. The MOE program takes a comprehensive approach to training undergraduates, and the co-curricular program integrates three modules: Working like a Scientist, Science Communication, and Career Exploration. Participants attended workshops and seminars on preparing for graduate school, developing presentation skills, scientific writing, research ethics, and achieving a greater understanding of evolutionary principles.  Supplemental funding supported a summer research experience for one Clark County high school teacher and two post-baccalaureate students.  All participants summarized their research for a poster presentation for the Summer Research Symposium.

 Overall, the MOE cohort was diverse; the majority (74%) were female (74%) and were from minoritized groups that are Historically Excluded Communities in Science (68.4%). There was also good representation from non-doctoral granting institutions (29%). Moreover, 60.5% of the participants were from institutions other than UNLV. Other descriptors highlighting the diversity of the REU participants include 8.0% being older than 30 years and 1.5% being veterans. The MOE program recruited nationally; participants attended colleges and universities from 9 states and DC. In addition, 66% of the participants attended HBCUs, Hispanic-serving, and two-year colleges.

A longitudinal survey determined that 53% of the former participants have 1) either entered or completed a graduate program (M.S., MAT, MSN, Ph.D.), 2) are employed at either a commercial or university laboratory, and 3) entered a STEM post-baccalaureate program intending to enter a graduate program. The STEM careers include lab technicians, clinical research coordinators, computer programmers, data scientists, and high school teachers. The remaining former participants are pursuing their baccalaureate degree, entering medical school, or recently graduated and seeking employment.  The leadership team is quite proud that one former participant, a Hispanic female who began college at a two-year institution, is a 2023 GRFP recipient.  In addition, five participants returned to their former UNLV REU lab for their graduate degrees. Lastly, there were 21 accepted publications with former REU participants co-authors attesting to the excellent science conducted at UNLV.   

 

 


Last Modified: 06/27/2023
Modified by: Kurt M Regner
